property.name: text
property.value: ssh identity file (for pwdless login)

property.name: text
property.value: Simulation machine? [user@]host :

property.name: text
property.value: job manager name: (e.g. PBS, Condor, LoadLeveler, SGE, Fork or LSF)

property.name: text
property.value: Remote directory where job script will be copied to and submitted from:

property.name: text
property.value: Job script (on local disk):

property.name: text
property.value: Log file (on local disk):

property.name: text
property.value: Log format (text or xml)

property.name: text
property.value:
This is an example workflow to submit jobs using actors including JobManager, JobSubmission and JobStatus. This workflow submits a local job script file ('JobScript' paramter) to the host ('SimTarget'), keeps checking its status until the job is finished.
To run the workflow, you need first to configure the parameters based on your information. If the value of the 'IdentityFile' parameter is empty, the 'SSH Session' actor will pop up a dialogue asking your account information.
The workflow supports multiple job schedulers: Condor, PBS, SGE, Fork, NCCS, LoadLeveler, LSF.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward A. Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure: Use the Annotation attribute to annotate a workflow. Double-click the attribute to customize the content, font size, color, and basic formatting (bold and italics).

property.name: prop:fontFamily
property.configure: The font face. Select a font from the drop-down menu. The default is "SansSerif".

property.name: prop:italic
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be italics. By default, type will not be italicized.

property.name: prop:bold
property.configure: Select to indicate that the type should be bold. By default, type will not be bold.

property.name: prop:textColor
property.configure: The font color. Specify a string representing an array of four elements: red, green, blue, and alpha, where alpha is transparency. The default is an opaque black, {0.0, 0.0, 0.0, 1.0}

property.name: prop:textSize
property.configure: The font size. Select an integer from the drop-down menu or specify a new size by typing it directly into the value field. The default is 14.

property.name: prop:text
property.configure: The text of the annotation.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Norbert Podhorszki

property.name: version
property.configure: $Id: JobManager.java 30678 2012-09-14 22:48:44Z jianwu $

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
Define a jobmanager on the local/remote machine

This actor uses the org.kepler.job.JobManagerFactory and org.kepler.job JobManager classes to define a job manager

The input should be:

  • the supporter class' name, e.g. Condor, PBS, LoadLeveler or whatever for that a class org.kepler.job.JobSupporter<name>.class exists
  • the target machine, either null, "" or "local" to denote a local jobmanager to be used by local execution command, OR "[user@]host" to denote a remote jobmanager to be used by an ssh connection.

The output is the created jobmanager of type ObjectToken, which should be given as parameter to a JobSubmitter.

On error, an empty string is returned.

property.name: port:binPath
property.configure: The path to the job manager commands on the target machines. Commands are constructed as binPath/command and they should be executable this way. This parameter is read each time in fire().

property.name: port:jmgr
property.configure: The created org.kepler.job.JobManager object as ObjectToken. This jmgr should be used in JobSubmitter to submit a job. This port is an output port of type ObjectToken.

property.name: port:target
property.configure: The machine to be used at job submission. It should be null, "" or "local" for the local machine or [user@]host to denote a remote machine accessible with ssh. This parameter is read each time in fire().

property.name: port:jobManager
property.configure: The name of the jobmanager to be used It should be a name, for which a supporter class exist as <i>org.kepler.job.JobSupport<jobManager>.class This parameter is read each time in fire().

property.name: prop:binPath
property.configure: The path to the job manager commands on the target machines. Commands are constructed as binPath/command and they should be executable this way. This parameter is read each time in fire().

property.name: prop:target
property.configure: The machine to be used at job submission. It should be null, "" or "local" for the local machine or [user@]host to denote a remote machine accessible with ssh. This parameter is read each time in fire().

property.name: prop:jobManager
property.configure: The name of the jobmanager to be used It should be a name, for which a supporter class exist as <i>org.kepler.job.JobSupport<jobManager>.class This parameter is read each time in fire().

property.name: description
property.value:
Define a jobmanager on the local/remote machine

This actor uses the org.kepler.job.JobManagerFactory and org.kepler.job JobManager classes to define a job manager

The input should be:

  • the supporter class' name, e.g. Condor, PBS, LoadLeveler or whatever for that a class org.kepler.job.JobSupporter<name>.class exists
  • the target machine, either null, "" or "local" to denote a local jobmanager to be used by local execution command, OR "[user@]host" to denote a remote jobmanager to be used by an ssh connection.

The output is the created jobmanager of type ObjectToken, which should be given as parameter to a JobSubmitter.

On error, an empty string is returned.

property.value: Norbert Podhorszki

property.value: $Id: JobManager.java 30678 2012-09-14 22:48:44Z jianwu $

property.name: jmgr (port)

property.name: binPath (port)

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Norbert Podhorszki, Chandrika Sivaramakrishnan, Jared Chase

property.name: version
property.configure: $Id: JobStatus.java 26613 2011-01-04 03:01:07Z chandrika $

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
Check the status of a Job

This actor uses the Job class to ask for the status of a submitted job.

The input should be a previously submitted job. i.e. the output from a JobSubmitter. When the job contains more than one task also provide the number of tasks using the numTasks parameter

Optional inputs - 1. you could specify the actor to wait for a specific status - for example Running 2. or wait till one of many status - for example Error,NotInQueue 3. Or you could ask the actor to all status changes as and when it is detected.

The output is the status code of the job:

  • 0: Error: some error occured during the execution of the actor
  • 1: NotInQueue: no such job in the queue, i.e. never was or already gone
  • 2: Wait: the job is in the queue and it is not running yet
  • 3: Running: the job is running

If not such job exists, the result will be also the Error status.

For convenience, the job is also passed on output port jobOut if the status is NOT Error and NOT NotInQueue. This token can be used (delaying it with a Sleep actor) to ask its Status again and again until the job is finished or aborted.

When numTasks input is greater than zero, in addition to job's overall status code the actor also outputs task id and task status of individual tasks

property.name: port:jobIn
property.configure: A submitted job This port is an output port of type Object.

property.name: port:logport
property.configure: Logging information of job status query. Useful to inform user about problems at unsuccessful status query but it also prints out job status and job id on successful query. This port is an output port of type String. The name of port on canvas is 'log'

property.name: port:jobOut
property.configure: The job is passed on in this actor. This token can be used (delaying it with a Sleep actor) to ask its Status again and again until the job is finished or aborted. This port is an output port of type Object.

property.name: port:taskId
property.configure: Task ID : this is the task id for the status code

property.name: port:statusCode
property.configure: Status code of the job 0 : for some error during execution or if jobID is invalid 1 : not in queue: i.e. already finished if it had ever been there (this is good news!) 2 : job is waiting in the queue 3 : job is running This port is an output port of type Integer;

property.name: port:taskStatusCode
property.configure: Task status code : for some error during execution or if jobID is invalid 1 : not in queue: i.e. already finished if it had ever been there (this is good news!) 2 : job is waiting in the queue 3 : job is running This port is an output port of type Integer;

property.name: prop:numTasks
property.configure: Parameter to set if the workflow is task parallel. This allows for the tasks to be created and set to the submitted state

property.name: prop:waitUntil
property.configure: Wait until the job has a specific status.

property.name: prop:statuscode_tokenProdRate
property.configure: The rate parameter for the output port.

property.name: prop:sendAllChanges
property.configure: Parameter to set if you want job status to ignore waitUntil parameter and send out every status change

property.name: prop:sleepWhileWaiting
property.configure: Amount of time (in milliseconds) to sleep between checking job status.

property.name: description
property.value:
Check the status of a Job

This actor uses the Job class to ask for the status of a submitted job.

The input should be a previously submitted job. i.e. the output from a JobSubmitter. When the job contains more than one task also provide the number of tasks using the numTasks parameter

Optional inputs - 1. you could specify the actor to wait for a specific status - for example Running 2. or wait till one of many status - for example Error,NotInQueue 3. Or you could ask the actor to all status changes as and when it is detected.

The output is the status code of the job:

  • 0: Error: some error occured during the execution of the actor
  • 1: NotInQueue: no such job in the queue, i.e. never was or already gone
  • 2: Wait: the job is in the queue and it is not running yet
  • 3: Running: the job is running

If not such job exists, the result will be also the Error status.

For convenience, the job is also passed on output port jobOut if the status is NOT Error and NOT NotInQueue. This token can be used (delaying it with a Sleep actor) to ask its Status again and again until the job is finished or aborted.

When numTasks input is greater than zero, in addition to job's overall status code the actor also outputs task id and task status of individual tasks

property.name: author
property.value: Norbert Podhorszki, Chandrika Sivaramakrishnan, Jared Chase

property.name: version
property.value: $Id: JobStatus.java 26613 2011-01-04 03:01:07Z chandrika $

property.name: numTasks (parameter)
property.value: Parameter to set if the workflow is task parallel. This allows for the tasks to be created and set to the submitted state

property.name: jobIn (port)
property.value: A submitted job This port is an output port of type Object.

property.name: jobOut (port)
property.value: The job is passed on in this actor. This token can be used (delaying it with a Sleep actor) to ask its Status again and again until the job is finished or aborted. This port is an output port of type Object.

property.name: taskId (port)
property.value: Task ID : this is the task id for the status code

property.name: taskStatusCode (port)
property.value: Task status code : for some error during execution or if jobID is invalid 1 : not in queue: i.e. already finished if it had ever been there (this is good news!) 2 : job is waiting in the queue 3 : job is running This port is an output port of type Integer;

property.name: statusCode (port)
property.value: Status code of the job 0 : for some error during execution or if jobID is invalid 1 : not in queue: i.e. already finished if it had ever been there (this is good news!) 2 : job is waiting in the queue 3 : job is running This port is an output port of type Integer;

property.name: logport (port)
property.value: Logging information of job status query. Useful to inform user about problems at unsuccessful status query but it also prints out job status and job id on successful query. This port is an output port of type String. The name of port on canvas is 'log'

property.name: waitUntil (parameter)
property.value: Wait until the job has a specific status.

property.name: statuscode_tokenProdRate (parameter)
property.value: The rate parameter for the output port.

property.name: sendAllChanges (parameter)
property.value: Parameter to set if you want job status to ignore waitUntil parameter and send out every status change

property.name: sleepWhileWaiting (parameter)
property.value: Amount of time (in milliseconds) to sleep between checking job status.

property.name: description
property.configure: null

property.name: author
property.configure: Edward Lee

property.name: version
property.configure: null

property.name: userLevelDocumentation
property.configure:
The StringConstant actor outputs a string specified via the actor's value parameter.

Specifying strings with the StringConstant actor is convenient, as the actor does not require that strings be surrounded by quotes. The actor is often used to specify file paths, which can be selected using the Browse button available in the actor's parameters.

Specified string values can include references to parameters within scope (i.e., parameters defined at the same level of the hierarchy or higher).

NOTE: If using a PN Director, the 'firingCountLimit' parameter is often set to a finite integer (e.g. '1') so that the workflow will terminate.

property.name: port:output
property.configure: An output port that broadcasts a string constant specified by the value parameter.

property.name: port:trigger
property.configure: A multiport that has no declared type (in other words, the port can accept any data type: double, int, array, etc.) If the port is connected, the actor will not fire until the trigger port receives an input token. Connecting the port is optional, but useful when scheduling the actor to perform at a certain time.

property.name: prop:firingCountLimit
property.configure: The limit on the number of times the actor will fire. The default value is 'NONE', meaning there is no limit on the number of time the constant will be provided to the output port. Any integer can be provided as a value for this parameter.

property.name: prop:value
property.configure: The value produced by the actor. Specified strings do not require enclosing quotes. (To include a '$' sign in the string, enter '$$'.)
